metadata.case_name: Sri Vedagiri Lakshmi Narasimha Swami Temple v. Respondent (Ex-Trustee)

facts.text: Sri Vedagiri Lakshmi Narasimha Swami temple situated at Narasimhuly konda, Nellore taluk, in the State of Andhra Pradesh, represented by its trustees (appellant).
Respondent and two others were hereditary trustees of the temple and functioned as such for a term of five years ending with January 1951. Respondent was the managing trustee during that period.
New trustees appointed by order of the Hindu Religious Endowments Board dated January 21, 1951 but obtained possession of the temple only on July 21, 1952.

New trustees filed O.S. No. 246 of 1953 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Nellore against respondent and others for: (1) rendition of accounts and payment of amounts due; (2) assessment of amounts due due to malfeasance, misfeasance and nonfeasance; (3) delivery of documents, accounts, registers, jewels and movable properties or value/damages.
Plaint alleged defendants guilty of acts of misfeasance, malfeasance, nonfeasance and gross negligence.
Defendants denied allegations and pleaded suit not maintainable in civil court in view of s.87 of Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951.

Subordinate Judge, by judgment dated August 12, 1953, held suit maintainable; found defendants liable to render accounts from beginning of 1946 to July 1952 and pay damages; passed preliminary decree directing respondent and defendants 2,5,6 to render accounts.

1st defendant (ex-managing trustee) appealed to District Judge, Nellore. Pending appeal, plaint amended: deleted words for damages from prayer 3; endorsement that plaintiffs gave up prayer for damages on 20-8-1958.
District Judge confirmed Subordinate Judge's decree; noted appellant did not press appeal on damages claim given up.

Andhra Pradesh High Court, Jaganmohan Reddy J., on Second Appeal, held suit for accounts not maintainable; noted plea for damages/negligence given up; relied on Venkataratnam v. Narasimha Rao and Sri Saraveswaraswami Vari temple v. Veerabhadrayya; allowed appeal, set aside lower decrees.
Ex-trustees did not give account of their management though put plaintiffs in possession in 1952 after obstructive attitude.

legal_issues.text: Whether a suit would lie at the instance of the present trustees of a temple for rendition of accounts of the management of the temple by the ex-trustees.
Whether s.93 of the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 is a bar to a suit by present trustees against ex-trustees for rendition of accounts.
Whether ex-trustee need render accounts only on allegations/proof of negligence or wilful default.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit was for damages for gross negligence; High Court Judge did not appreciate correct scope of concession made by advocate.
Section 93 of the Act is not a bar to suit by present trustees against ex-trustees for rendition of accounts and recovery of amounts due.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 s.93

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit for back-accounting would lie; ex-trustees liable irrespective of negligence.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit not maintainable in civil court due to s.87/93 of the Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 s.87, s.93

respondent_arguments.text: Chapter VII of the Act provides complete machinery for rendition of accounts; no suit lies dehors the Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 Ch.VII

respondent_arguments.text: Plea of wilful default/damages given up; only general accounting claimed, which does not lie without wilful default.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Venkataratnam v. Narasimha Rao; Sri Saraveswaraswami Vari temple v. Veerabhadrayya

court_reasoning.text: In view of unambiguous concession by appellant's advocate before High Court, suit confined to rendition of accounts of management, not on ground of wilful default/negligence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Concession limits scope to general accounts.

court_reasoning.text: No trustee can get discharge unless renders accounts of management; liability irrespective of negligence/wilful default. Ex-trustees liable as did not account despite possession handover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguished precedents like V.K. Kelu Achan and Madura Devasthanams as context-specific.

court_reasoning.text: Period of accounts: from 1946 to July 1952 reasonable; no interference with lower courts' discretion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Attorney General v. Exeter Mayor; limits based on equity.

court_reasoning.text: S.93 bars suits only for administration/management or matters where Act provides machinery; suit against ex-trustees not covered as Ch.VII concerns current trustees' accounts/audit/surcharge.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.93 not total bar; history from CPC s.92, earlier Acts supports narrow construction.

court_reasoning.text: Ch.VII (ss.70-74) for current management supervision, audit, surcharge; does not cover ex-trustees; s.74(7) implies suits possible outside surcharged matters.
Distinguished Andhra HC cases: Venkataratnam involved current breaches under Act; Sarveswaraswami not for management.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.93 applies only to provided matters.

holdings.text: Present trustees can sue ex-trustees for rendition of accounts of management without alleging negligence/wilful default.
S.93 of the Act not a bar as no provision in Act for such suit against ex-trustees.
Lower courts correctly directed accounts from 1946 to July 1952.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on for no general accounting without default; SC distinguished as suit under Act provisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Saraveswaraswami Vari temple v. Veerabhadrayya
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on; SC noted limits s.93 to specific matters.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. K. Kelu Achan v. C.S. Sivarama Pattar
precedents_cited.relevance: No back accounting without dishonesty; observations contextual, not absolute rule.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Madura etc. Devasthanams v. Doraiswami Nayudu
precedents_cited.relevance: No wilful default, no accounts; not authority for no accounts without default.
No fixed time limit for trustee accounts; courts fix period per equity.
CPC s.92(2) not bar suits by trustee for accounts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tirumalai Tirupati Devasthanam Committee v. Udiavar Krishnayya Sahnbhaga
precedents_cited.relevance: CPC s.92 not for personal trustee rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Manjeshwar Srimad Anantheswar Temple v. Vaikunta Bhakta
precedents_cited.relevance: S.73(4) of 1927 Act not total bar.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Sarveswaraswami Vari Temple v. Rudrapaka Veerabhadrayya
precedents_cited.relevance: S.93 two limbs; suit for property recovery not barred.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 (Act 19 of 1951)
statutes_cited.relevance: S.93 not bar to suit for ex-trustee accounts as no machinery in Act; Ch.VII for current trustees only.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Courts jurisdiction unless barred; s.92 not for trustee vs ex-trustee accounts.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 2 of 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: Predecessor; phrase 'except under...Act' judicially construed narrowly.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court set aside Andhra Pradesh High Court decree, restored Subordinate Judge's preliminary decree directing ex-trustees to render true and proper account of temple management from beginning of 1946 to July 1952 and pay amounts due.
outcome.costs: Respondent to pay costs of appellant throughout.

key_quotes.text: It is common place that no trustee can get a discharge unless he renders accounts of his management. This liability is irrespective of any question of negligence or wilful default.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on trustee liability for accounts.

key_quotes.text: Section 93 of the Act does not impose a total bar on the maintainability of a suit in a civil court.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Chapter VII only provides for a strict supervision of the financial side of the administration of an institution... It has nothing to do with the management of a temple by a previous trustee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
